qas.question: Which two dialects were banned from public life?
What did the banning of the two dialects  include?

answers.text: street and city names, official administration, and educational system

qas.question: Although Aslation is rarely used today, which region still uses their mother language of Aslation?
What other language besides French and German are part of the Aslation-French dialect of today?
What is the name of the region where Yiddish is primarily spoken?
What area is primarily Standard German in culture?
Most young people speak what form of German?
What is Yiddish primarily influenced by?

context: Both <a0_0><b4_0>Alsatian and <b7_0>Standard<b7_0/> German<b4_0/><a0_0/> were for a time banned from public life (including <a1_0>street and city names, official administration, and educational system<a1_0/>). Though the ban has long been lifted and street signs today are often bilingual, <b6_0>Alsace-Lorraine<b6_0/> is today very French in language and culture. Few young people speak Alsatian today, although there do still exist one or two enclaves in the <a2_0><b5_0>Sundgau<b5_0/> region<a2_0/> where some older inhabitants cannot speak French, and where Alsatian is still used as the mother tongue. A related Alemannic German survives on the opposite bank of the Rhine, in Baden, and especially in Switzerland. However, while French is the major language of the region, the Alsatian dialect of French is heavily influenced by <b8_0>German<b8_0/> and other languages such a <a3_0>Yiddish<a3_0/> in phonology and vocabulary.
